results.title: Silent Number
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Jamie Blanks and Hugh Burton
results.brief_description: Babysitter Nicole is subjected to a horrific night of phone calls from a guy called Matt, claiming to be beaten by his father and imprisoned in a cold place. When a bloodied man comes to the door claiming that he and his wife have been in an accident, she decides it is time to call the police. Cast includes Bronwyn Jones and John Brumpton.

results.title: Robert Klippel
results.creator_credit: Keith Salvat, Keisal Films and Australia Council
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Painters, the sculptors: archival art series”.
Robert Klippel is viewed as one of Australia’s most important artists of the fifties and sixties. His humble beginnings (and obsession) with ship modelmaking was to influence and inform his work throughout his career as an artist. Klippel was a self-taught artist whose interest sprung from the processes he’d developed while model building, a scale which was to continue in his work throughout his career. Klippel had a strong preference for the solid built form of sculpture but found his work naturally becoming more linear in style. His developed language in the fifties and his need for intellectual peers saw him travel to Europe and New York to again resettle in Sydney, Australia where he developed strong artistic allies and his notoriety as an abstract expressionist artist along with Olsen and Passmore. This documentary charts Klippel’s role in a developing cultural nation.

results.title: Phar Lap: the people's champion [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Eddie Carnana, Michael Dickinson, Rhett Kirkwood and Hall of Fame Corporation
results.brief_description: The People’s champion, Phar Lap, is an icon of Australia’s past. This video contains previously unseen footage of the greatest thoroughbred there ever was. Footage is contributed featuring Tommy Woodcock, Harry Telford and American businessman David Davis, as well as including the amazing story of Cups King Bart Cummings, whose record 10 Melbourne Cup triumphs is equally worthy of praise.

results.title: Pilkington Brothers offer: the best of both worlds
results.creator_credit: Frank Worth, Cecil Musk and British Information Services
results.brief_description: Two visitors from outer space visit Earth in order to investigate a material unknown on their planet - glass. They are shown the many architectural uses of glass and the many varieties which are available for use.

results.title: Ram sales
results.brief_description: This is a general interest film which shows typical scenes at the annual Sydney sheep show, including judging. It also illustrates the different areas of country in relation to ram types, and shows various wool fabrics and types of wool from which fabrics are manufactured. Photography by Tom Price and commentary by Wilfred Thomas.

results.title: RAAF Newsreel. No. 9. Operation sabre ferry
results.creator_credit: Harry Rayner and Australia. Royal Australian Air Force
results.brief_description: Newsreel items including: 1. No. 3 Squadron and No. 77 Squadron of the RAAF ferry the Sabre Jet from the east coast of Australia to Butterworth in Malaya via Townsville, Darwin, Netherlands New Guinea, Philippines, Borneo, Malaya. 2. Firefighter - RAAF demonstrates capability of new firefighting truck. 3. Addition of the new Air to Air Missile to the Sabre Jet Fighter. Test fired at Woomera.

results.title: Service to the inland (A)
results.creator_credit: J. Campbell Dobbie and Peerless Films
results.brief_description: A story of the inland telegraph, demonstrating the need for and efficiency of the inland communications system. Shows a message from a Northern Territory bush wireless to Dunlop Tyres translated into a narrative about developments in the outback (transportation, primary industry, the flying doctor etc.). Also includes footage of Aboriginal couriers travelling overland on foot, Aboriginal settlements, their culture, cooking, food gathering etc, in particular Emily’s Gap.
